I'm Michelle. I design websites and user experiences. That means I specialize in clarity, structure and kindness. Read my thoughts here, or see my latest work. You can say hello, too!

Why do it the easy way?

Posted on 14 October 2013 about Jekyll, GitHub, Markdown, Liquid.

“But why,” I ask myself, “why should I use systems built by very smart people to suit a wide variety of website needs when I can spend time and energy making my own from scratch?” Why indeed.

I’ve decided to take my understanding of how The Interwebz works to a new level. This thing called GitHub has always been “that strange place with the phallic logo that programmers wax poetic about.” Lately, several people have been convincing me of the potential of GitHub to do lots of cool stuff (like make government policy more open and accessible, for example, but taking the programmer framework of versioning and forking and contributing, and expanding it to new fields).

Yeah, ok. But GitHub is still a non-programmer usability nightmare. Is it all online, or is this something I have to command line? (answer: both online and computer GUI or command) How the hell do I upload something? (answer: you can’t. you have to use that command line or computer GUI to ‘upload’ files)(long story).

But, money where your mouth is, right? I need to update my personal website anyways, so let’s effing bleeding edge it, eh?

Hosting entirely in GitHub

I’ve decided to take my understanding of how The Interwebz works to a new level. This thing called GitHub has always been “that strange place with the phallic logo that programmers wax poetic about.” Lately, several people have been convincing me of the potential of GitHub to do lots of cool stuff (like make government policy more open and accessible, for example, but taking the programmer framework of versioning and forking and contributing, and expanding it to new fields).

Yeah, ok. But GitHub is still a non-programmer usability nightmare. Is it all online, or is this something I have to command line? (answer: both online and computer GUI or command) How the hell do I upload something? (answer: you can’t. you have to use that command line or computer GUI to ‘upload’ files)(long story).

Setting up Jekyll

First go here: http://jekyllrb.com/

Then, for, like, background on what the hell you’re doing, go here: http://jekyllbootstrap.com/lessons/jekyll-introduction.html

MadeMistakes

http://www.andrewmunsell.com/tutorials/jekyll-by-example/index.html#starting-your-website

http://www.divshot.com/blog/web-development/advanced-jekyll-features/

Liquid

OH shit, another templating language to learn. Ballz. https://github.com/Shopify/liquid/wiki/Liquid-for-Designers

Ronét Jewelry

Posted on 02 October 2013.

Ronét Jewelry is a growing small business based in Silver Spring, Maryland that wanted to expand to online sales. Online sales meant Ronét needed a website!
→ continue reading →

American Mandarin Society

Posted on 01 August 2013.

The American Mandarin Society is a new organization composed of a younger generation of Mandarin scholars who have studied, researched and lived in Greater China. It needed a mark that would reflect its scholarly background, but also point to the group’s modern, youthful focus.
→ continue reading →

Howard Needham Violins

Posted on 01 May 2013.

Howard Needham, a luthier based in Silver Spring, Maryland, needed an update to his old Flash-based site that would be structured to modern web standards. My site design puts the focus where it should be: on his beautiful instruments.
→ continue reading →

NOAA IIAD Outreach

Posted on 27 April 2013.

The NOAA Satellite and Information Service (NESDIS) had a problem: no one knew that it flew satellites! (“Satellites? Isn’t that NASA?”) I worked with an internal NOAA-NESDIS team to strategize better outreach methods that told the NOAA-NESDIS story proactively, rather than reactively.
→ continue reading →

About This Site

Behind the curtain My site is powered by Jekyll, a Ruby-based site generator that uses Liquid as its templating language. It is hosted entirely on GitHub (thanks to Kin Lane and his Hacker Storytelling for the technique!).

On stage My design was built on top of Skeleton, a bare-bones responsive framework. Fonts are Bree from Type Together, and Freight Sans from Darden Studio.
